channel.title: I'm retarded, file reading

item.title: I'm retarded, file reading
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Since the answer is somewhat scattered between posts, and due to my lack of entertainment at the time of this post, I’ll go ahead and restate everything in a ‘cleaner’ format. Oh, and yes, I know you already solved this, but others in the future may want to know as well.

The bug in you’re code can be pinpointed to right here:

	            while (s.hasNext()) {
	            	if (s.equals(lol))
	                	System.out.println("its equal");
	            	
	                System.out.println(s.next());
	            }

Or even more so:

	            	if (s.equals(lol))

Variable s is a Scanner object, while variable lol is a String object. Two objects, when compared, will never equal each other. In Java, an object’s toString() method return’s the object in its own String representation (so the equals() method is comparing two Strings).

Let’s go even deeper. Your Scanner object would look somewhat like this (taken straight out of the API’s source code):

    public String toString() {
        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
	sb.append("java.util.Scanner");
	sb.append("[delimiters=" + delimPattern + "]");
	sb.append("[position=" + position + "]");
	sb.append("[match valid=" + matchValid + "]");
	sb.append("[need input=" + needInput + "]");
	sb.append("[source closed=" + sourceClosed + "]");
        sb.append("[skipped=" + skipped + "]");
        sb.append("[group separator=" + groupSeparator + "]");
        sb.append("[decimal separator=" + decimalSeparator + "]");
        sb.append("[positive prefix=" + positivePrefix + "]");
	sb.append("[negative prefix=" + negativePrefix + "]");
	sb.append("[positive suffix=" + positiveSuffix + "]");
	sb.append("[negative suffix=" + negativeSuffix + "]");
	sb.append("[NaN string=" + nanString + "]");
	sb.append("[infinity string=" + infinityString + "]");
	return sb.toString();
    }

When calling the toString() method on the String object, it returns itself. You can already see that the entire String representation differs from Scanner to String, as each class/instance/object has its own set of fields/paramters and own unique name/type.

So to conclude that part of this little speech, different objects, when compared, are always different. It doesn’t matter if you made your own String class with the value “hello world” and compared it to Sun’s String class with the value “hello world”, because even then the class’s name and/or type is unique and different from one another (yours would be something like test.type.String and theres would be java.lang.String).

To fix this, you’ll have to use a String representation of the value being inputted into the console, instead of the actual Scanner object itself. Here’s a tidied up and fixed version of your code:

              //Read on a continous level until the Scanner object does not have any input
              while (s.hasNext()) 
              {
                     //Read the String inputted by the user
                     String theInput = s.next();
                     if (theInput.equals(lol))
                     {
                            //Display message indicating the two Strings are equal to one another.   
                            System.out.println("its equal");
                     }
                     System.out.println(s.next());
              }

You can see a difference here. Instead of comparing the Scanner object itself, we compare the String inputted into the console by the user to the String you are checking for (which in this case is “0:4”).

That’s all.

item.title: I'm retarded, file reading
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“k00dr, post:9, topic:231121”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=304380.msg2439962#msg2439962 date=1221413469]
if (s.next().equals(lol))
System.out.println(“its equal”);

                System.out.println(s.next());
            }[/quote]

It’s because you read two tokens a round :)[/quote]Ha, thanks. Now I see why it hopped over some numbers.

[quote=“Taharok, post:10, topic:231121”]Mopar just said to make sure you don’t call [tt]s.next()[/tt] twice. The Scanner acts as an iterator, so by calling [tt]next()[/tt] again, you are really skipping an index. You need to change it to the following:

[code]
while (s.hasNext()) {
String current = s.next();
if (current.equals(lol))
System.out.println(“its equal”);
System.out.println(current);

current = null;

}
[/code][/quote]

That’s exactly what I needed, thanks.

Read full topic

item.title: I'm retarded, file reading
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Mopar just said to make sure you don’t call [tt]s.next()[/tt] twice. The Scanner acts as an iterator, so by calling [tt]next()[/tt] again, you are really skipping an index. You need to change it to the following:

while (s.hasNext()) {
	String current = s.next();
	if (current.equals(lol))
		System.out.println("its equal");
	System.out.println(current);

	current = null;
}

@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I changed it to this:

[code]while (s.hasNext()) {

            	if (s.next().equals(lol))
                	System.out.println("its equal");
            	
                System.out.println(s.next());
            }[/code]

This gives me the following:

its equal 1 3 5 7

This isn’t correct for two reasons. First it doesn’t print the complete file. Second, if I change lol to 5 it can’t find it.

item.title: I'm retarded, file reading
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[code]while (s.hasNext()) {
if (s.equals(lol))
System.out.println(“its equal”);

System.out.println(s.next());
[/code]

s.equals(lol)

s is a Scanner object, correct?
lol is a String object, correct?
2 different objects can never equal one another.

You need to compare lol to what you are actually printing, you aren’t printing s, you are printing s.next() (make sure not to call s.next() twice per loop though, save it and use it twice.

item.title: I'm retarded, file reading
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I feel quite retarded here, and a bit ashamed to ask this. Anyways, what am I doing wrong here. I try to find a number in a text file, but it doesn’t work.

Text file:

0:4
1
2
3
4
5
6
7

Source:

        import java.io.*;
	import java.util.Scanner;

	public class listComparer {
	    
		public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
	        Scanner s = null;
	        String lol = "0:4";
	        try {
	            s = new Scanner(new BufferedReader(new FileReader("c://list.txt")));

	            while (s.hasNext()) {
	            	if (s.equals(lol))
	                	System.out.println("its equal");
	            	
	                System.out.println(s.next());
	            }
	            
	        } finally {
	            if (s != null) {
	                s.close();
	            }
	        }
	    }
	}

It’s just something to test my knowledge about the subject before actually making stuff around it. Obviously, I know nothing about it.

Edit: BTW, I took most of the source from the Java tutorial. It was supposed to just print what the file contained, and it did. So don’t go crazy at me for not writing it.

Read full topic
